CatDescriptText: Mr. John Jordan, construction worker, Library, Pa. and Miss Juanita Tolliver, student, Hill District, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, July 14, 1962, pg. 17 with question: "Do you think it is ethical or right for a doctor to go on 'strike' as a protest?"  Mr. Jordan's answer reads: "I don't believe its ethical for a doctor to strike, for in doing so, they have to stand by and watch sick people suffer when they could do something to help them."  Ms. Tolliver's answer reads: "No, I don't.  Most doctors seem to be dedicated to the job of helping their fellowman.  He has to have some sort of a conscience about the things he does."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of John Jordan wearing eyeglasses and shirt with two breast pockets and rolled sleeves, standing in front of C.A. Michel store with Pittsburgh Paints sign, Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Juanita Tolliver wearing eyeglasses and light colored blouse with wide collar and bow at neckline, standing in front of trolley car, three women, and young boy
